step_by_step: Identify the key difference between laminar and turbulent boundary layers on an airfoil.
Laminar boundary layers have a smoother, more ordered flow, with lower kinetic energy near the surface.
Turbulent boundary layers have a 'fuller' velocity profile, with higher momentum fluid closer to the surface.
The higher momentum of the turbulent boundary layer allows it to better withstand adverse pressure gradients on the upper surface of the airfoil.
This delay in flow separation for the turbulent boundary layer results in it remaining attached over a longer distance compared to the laminar boundary layer.
